ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about what ethnography was and how it differs from other fields within Sociology.
I developed the knowledge, skills, and insights needed to become an urban ethnographer.

I learned that Ethnography is the systematic study of culture and that it is important to "get in" with your subjects. Though "getting in" is an organic process and very hard to definitively layout the process.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Learned about a variety of current ethnographic studies Weakness: Would have liked more time to engage with the presenters.
Dr. Anderson is the premier expert in urban ethnography. Only strengths, no weaknesses.
Although this was a speakers series, I thought more class that discussed the ins and outs of ethnography would have been very useful for first time students in this field.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It was a great survey course. I enjoyed the professor's candor and insight into the field.
Yes, only if you are serious about ethnography.
yes, i think methodologically this class is very useful
